message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including leg pain, swelling, pitting edema, and inability to fully compress the lumen of the profunda femoris vein on ultrasound, suggest the most likely diagnosis is deep venous thrombosis. Superficial venous thrombophlebitis would not cause the inability to compress the lumen. Erythema nodosum is not associated with leg swelling or dilated veins. Ruptured popliteal cyst would not cause the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of recent hospitalization and congestive heart failure exacerbation increases her risk for deep venous thrombosis. The physical examination findings, as well as the results of the venous duplex ultrasound, support this diagnosis. Superficial venous thrombophlebitis would typically present with localized redness, warmth, and tenderness, but not with swelling of an entire leg. Erythema nodosum and ruptured popliteal cyst are less likely diagnoses based on the given information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has left leg pain, swelling, and superficial dilated veins, which are all suggestive of Deep Venous Thrombosis (DVT). The inability to fully compress the lumen of the profunda femoris vein on the ultrasound also supports the diagnosis of DVT. Superficial venous thrombophlebitis would not cause significant calf swelling or deep vein inability to compress. Erythema nodosum and ruptured popliteal cyst are unlikely to present with leg pain and swelling.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of leg pain, swelling, and superficial dilated veins suggest a possible deep venous thrombosis. The inability to fully compress the lumen of the profunda femoris vein on ultrasound confirms the diagnosis. Superficial venous thrombophlebitis and erythema nodosum do not cause calf swelling and dilated superficial veins, while a ruptured popliteal cyst may cause swelling and pain but not dilated superficial veins.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of left leg pain, swelling, and inability to fully compress the lumen of the profunda femoris vein on ultrasound suggest deep venous thrombosis. Superficial venous thrombophlebitis would not cause such a significant difference in calf circumference, while erythema nodosum and ruptured popliteal cyst do not typically present with edema and dilated veins.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has left leg pain and swelling, and a venous duplex ultrasound shows an inability to fully compress the lumen of the profunda femoris vein, which indicates deep venous thrombosis. Superficial venous thrombophlebitis usually presents with erythema and tenderness over the surface veins, and erythema nodosum is typically a painful rash on the shins. Ruptured popliteal cyst may cause swelling but is unlikely to cause pain and inability to compress the vein.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The leg pain and swelling, along with the inability to fully compress the lumen of the profunda femoris vein, suggest deep venous thrombosis. Superficial venous thrombophlebitis would not cause significant edema or dilation of veins. Erythema nodosum presents as tender nodules without significant edema or dilation of veins. Ruptured popliteal cyst would not cause significant edema or dilation of veins.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of left leg pain, swelling, and superficial dilated veins suggest deep venous thrombosis (DVT), which is confirmed by the venous duplex ultrasound showing inability to fully compress the lumen of the profunda femoris vein. Superficial venous thrombophlebitis also causes leg pain and swelling, but does not have pitting edema or dilated veins. Erythema nodosum and ruptured popliteal cyst would not present in this way.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of leg pain, swelling, and dilated veins suggest DVT (deep venous thrombosis). The inability to fully compress the lumen of the profunda femoris vein on ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis. Superficial venous thrombophlebitis would only cause surface-level symptoms and erythema nodosum is usually associated with systemic diseases. Ruptured popliteal cyst may cause pain and swelling but not to the extent described in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Left leg pain and swelling, along with the presence of dilated veins, suggest deep venous thrombosis. The inability to fully compress the lumen of the profunda femoris vein on venous duplex ultrasound confirms the diagnosis. None of the other options fit the clinical presentation or examination findings.
